1.text: >> Hello, and welcome again to this edition of Capital Dateline.  I'm your host, Brad Swanson.

5.text: We're coming to you just a few blocks from Florida's Capitol,

7.text: from the headquarters of the Florida Cable Telecommunications Association.

11.text: I, today, am joined by the digital media leaders of Florida.

16.text: In our studio today we have Matt Dixon who is the Florida Bureau Chief for Politico Florida.

21.text: We're also joined by Brian Burgess who is the Publisher of the Capitolist, aka Peter Schorsch, Jr.

27.text: We have Peter Schorsch, Publisher of FloridaPolitics.com,

31.text: and Trimmel Gomes, President of Gomes Media, host of The Rotunda, and definitely

36.text: the best dressed guy in the room today. Gentlemen, welcome. Welcome to the show.

40.text: Alright so we've got a few weeks left in this year's legislative session.

45.text: We've had tons of just crazy issues, stuff Florida's never seen, from marijuana implementation

50.text: to what, we've seen gambling before and gaming law, but how would you guys describe

56.text: the state of affairs in the Capitol, everywhere from the Governor's office, to the Speaker,

60.text: to the President. What are we seeing out there? Dealer's choice, who wants to go first?

64.text: >> This is the time of the year I would say when the House and the Senate can't agree if

68.text: the sky is blue, and you know, some of it's by design and it's a lot of fun to watch.

71.text: They're fighting over some of the biggest issues of the day.

74.text: They're fighting over all the things we talked about. They can't agree on medical marijuana.

76.text: We're going into a gaming conference, final gaming negotiations, and they're miles apart,

81.text: so right now the dynamic, and the Governor will get in later at the last week or so

85.text: and when veto season comes, but right now it's largely a big fight between the House and the Senate.

89.text: That's traditional, and it's a good spectator sport.

92.text: >> Right, so you're characterizing this as traditional?

95.text: >> I would say, I think early in session when there was a lot of budget questions going on

99.text: it felt a little different, it felt like for sure we were gonna go into a special session

102.text: and face this train wreck, but I think some of the tension we see at the end of session here

105.text: feels much more traditional. A lot of big issues yet, so it's certainly a lot of fights out there,

110.text: but it feels like more of a traditional session as opposed to some of the doom and gloom

114.text: we were hearing about earlier.  >> Right, right. Alright, Burgess?

117.text: >> I would say that, yeah, there is the doom and gloom, and in all the six years

120.text: I've seen this stuff play out. I would agree with you, it's the same thing.

124.text: It's always the fretting and the hand-wringing from lobbyists who aren't getting their way.

127.text: And there's a lot of them aren't getting their way, but there is one sort of elephant in the room,

132.text: and that is what is Richard Corcoran really gonna do and what is he up to, and does he really

138.text: need to bring session in for a landing or does he benefit politically by creating a train wreck?

143.text: >> Well, what do you think as media professionals?

146.text: >> I'll carry that ball a little further down the field. I think that there are some who would argue

152.text: that Richard Corcoran has everything to gain by stretching this thing out a little bit longer

157.text: and carrying it out. He can raise money during the down time between the end of session -

164.text: if there's a sine dine on time - and then we have that break period before,

168.text: maybe the tail end of June when we come back, he can raise money, and he can raise money on

173.text: issues he may have scuttled, so not a bad political move for him.

176.text: He gets to play the role of the fixer or the guy who's, I'm gonna hold the line on some of these

183.text: conservative issues, and he gets all the headlines.

186.text: >> And with his base, the swath of voters that he would aim at either at the Senate race or

189.text: the Gubernatorial race, this stuff speaks perfectly to them.

191.text: So to your point, I don't think most...I think most would argue that Richard Corcoran

195.text: has a political benefit of extending this thing and perhaps a special session,

198.text: whether it happens or not, I don't know, but I agree with the point that it would be

201.text: politically beneficial to the Speaker.  >> Trimmel, what say you?

204.text: >> Same thing. Once you're outside of this bubble, what else is going on,

208.text: so they need to stay here.  Everyone would like to be in Corcoran's head to see what's going on.

213.text: It's a benefit to him to extend because otherwise once you leave the session,

217.text: you're back to your district, and there's nothing going on. How do you grab those headlines?

221.text: So staying here, throwing some stuff in the air and seeing where they fall and

225.text: grabbing as much media attention, having us write about it and cover it,

228.text: is the way to get headlines to benefit his future.

231.text: >> So we hear it here first, Trimmel Gomes wants to get into the head of Richard Corcoran.

236.text: >> I would like to sit down and hey...

238.text: >> We can make quite a fortune on him cause there's a lot of people who want to be in

240.text: Richard Corcoran's head right now and understand what he's doing.

243.text: >> The most famous podcast in the country if you figure out how to do that.  >> Peter, what say you?

247.text: >> I'm good. I think it's unsurprising. I think they're playing to form.

252.text: I think when Richard Corcoran won this Speaker Designate we knew this was coming.

259.text: We knew that Joe Negron was going to be a relatively milquetoast, trial lawyer-loving

265.text: Senate President who has relatively weaker lieutenants than other leaders

274.text: and so this is playing to form. Now that doesn't mean that we know how the script is going to end

280.text: but Jack Latvala is the bear, the Governor is uninterested, Richard Corcoran's Machiavellian

286.text: and Joe Negron is milquetoast, and so you could have written this in January of 2014

295.text: >> I wouldn't say necessarily weaker lieutenants but lieutenants who don't agree with their

298.text: President as much as say the lieutenants agree with their Speakers.

301.text: To your point about being trial lawyer-loving, some of his top lieutenants are more traditional,

304.text: business-friendly Republicans, and I think there's some inherent policy tensions between the two of them

309.text: so I think as, individually, a Bill Galvano and a Jack Latvala, a Wilton Simpson are all strong members

313.text: it's just they don't necessarily have their Presidents' back the way we've historically seen that work.

318.text: >> I was referring to...I mean his two chief leutenants would be

321.text: Anitere Flores and Lizbeth Benacquisto. >> You would refer to them as being weak?

325.text: >> I would say they were weaker than previous lieutenants. I think you need a hammer in there.

329.text: I don't like Tom Lee's politics, but when he was appropriation's chair, when he was part of it,

334.text: he was a hammer, and I think that there is a...Joe Negron is not being served very well right now.

340.text: Anitere Flores has been probably one of the bigger disappointments of session, has been criticized

345.text: across the board from Sunshine State News to the Miami Herald, from our sites.

349.text: She has not had a very strong session, and so I think then you're right, the host unto themselves,

357.text: Simpson, Galvano, they've carved out their own future Senate President seat, you're right.

362.text: They're not in line with Negron and then you've got the big bear out there, Latvala,

366.text: growling at Tiger Bay saying we're not gonna get done until June 30.

370.text: >> Right. It's difficult to be weak but also be a state lawmaker and get noticed by the Wall Street Journal.

375.text: The Wall Street Journal has written editorials critical of Anitere Flores.

378.text: The idea that, while I'm sure some folks made phone calls up there, the idea that you got a

382.text: paper like that to bite on a state lawmaker. I don't know I'm fully there that it was

386.text: completely weak or completely unnoticed, because I think the Senate and some of its policy fights

391.text: are getting noticed on a larger level and sometimes historically they are.

395.text: >> But I would say the Senate, looks like, to form to your point, is typically a bunch of

400.text: independent leaders versus the House which is operating in a machine-like manner,

405.text: meaning top-down, relatively moving forward based upon who the leadership is.

409.text: Okay, so let's move on to what they're working on. What do you guys think will be the

414.text: bills that survive, the big appropriations that survive, and make it to Governor Scott's desk

421.text: and ultimately what do you think he actually signs?

424.text: >> I think you'll see a tradeoff for the education funding. I think the House gets its charters.

428.text: They want funding for what they call Schools of Hope. $200 million for charter schools.

433.text: I think that that gets traded for Joe Negron's top priority which is additional money for higher education.

439.text: I think that that's one of the places where we're see agreement as Alexandra Glorioso reported today,

444.text: she's with the Naples Daily News. There's a preliminary offer on gambling that the

451.text: Senate may be moving a little bit towards the House's angle right there.

455.text: That might be something...I think one of the interesting maneuvers this week is by the

459.text: marijuana people, John Morgan, Ben Pollara, they are now calling for the implementing bill

468.text: to be opposed, and so we may get out of here without a marijuana bill, which will be really

474.text: counter to what the voters had asked. I think it was 71% wanting that.

478.text: >> What's very interesting, John Morgan and Ben Pollara - John Morgan obviously the trial lawyer -

482.text: the idea is that he would want a bill to pass that he opposes so he can take it to court.

486.text: Who'd a thunk it? Who'd a thunk it?  >> Job security...right...right? >> Who'd a thunk it?

491.text: >> Trimell? >> The bill that we're not talking about, or a bevy of bills, is guns.

496.text: The gun lobby, and to Peter's point earlier looking at Anitere Flores,

502.text: the one who's feeling the heat from all of those gun bills not making it through,

506.text: that is something to commend to be able to go up against.  >> A lot of gun owners in Florida.

515.text: >> It's to be seen what the blow back will be to Anitere Flores after this, her future,

521.text: what's next for her, cause we've seen in past, people do not fare well when they go up against the lobby.

527.text: >> The NRA finally being popped at this point that they are all powerful,

532.text: I mean they've switched committee chairs. They thought that was the big issue,

537.text: that if they had a new committee chair, they would get in these bills,

539.text: and they're running into the same problems.

541.text: >> The formation of that committee is still very, it's sort of the switcheroo,

545.text: you give them a chairman so it looks like those bills are gonna pass

548.text: but the makeup of some of the South Florida Republicans on that committee, Judiciary committee still

552.text: >> You can't have open carry down in South Beach, That just wouldn't work.

556.text: >> It's hard to strap to a bikini. >> It's not hard it just looks funny. >> Right?  Right?

561.text: Have any of you tried that? That's a little weird. So let's move on.

564.text: So we're looking at bills, any other bills we need to be bird-dogging?

568.text: I mean Uber had just passed this week. That's a huge bill to get across both Chambers

575.text: and on its way to the Governor. I know Cesar at Uber are celebrating to high heaven right now.

581.text: >> Yea we haven't seen Cesar  >> Trimmel? I heard they were out at Top Flight golf many hours after.

594.text: >> Back on the record. >> That's a big win for the ridesharing community.

600.text: I think it's been talked about that's it's one of the best legislations in favor of them across the country.

606.text: >> You remember when Senator Brandes was the first one to just opine on the fact that

610.text: you would get off in what is arguably - not what is arguably - the third largest state in the nation

615.text: and your app would be dead in a global app. That was two or three years ago.

619.text: >> A new Senate President makes all the difference. I think last year President Gardiner was

623.text: certainly not in favor of it. He bottled that thing up, and here we are.

627.text: >> I'll say this, I was talking to a business leader the other day. >> Peter, he was talking to Peter.

634.text: >> No it was not Peter, but the sentiment was I can't believe that the ridesharing legislation

641.text: is the biggest win for businesses that we have to talk about right now.

644.text: This person was beside him or herself. I'm paraphrasing but there was like this incredulously

652.text: opining about how this is the only thing that had really gotten done that's innovative,

658.text: that's forward-looking for businesses at this point.

660.text: So there's a little bit of disappointment, I think, in the business community.

662.text: >> I spoke with a business leader as well, and you're right a couple of the issues that

669.text: we aren't talking about that are in play are some of the big insurance issues.

671.text: They're talking about repealing PIP, which would be, that will be one of those issues

676.text: that hits every Floridian in the pocket book. I think it's like a $400 million swing.

680.text: Worker's Comp, I think, is still in play. The House has passed its bill.

683.text: The Senate's like, ah, we don't want to do that but there are..

686.text: the insurance lobbyists are gonna be busy these next two weeks either killing or pushing some legislation.

691.text: >> Well, it's just different this year with those guys.

692.text: The insurance lobbyists and the business lobby are good at defense, they're strong in the Capitol,

698.text: but for the first time in a while they're not on offense, not the trial lawyers on defense.

701.text: It's reversed this year. So they might kill some of the most toxic stuff,

704.text: and I'm skeptical that some of those bills we just talked about can actually pass,

706.text: but their muscles are still being flexed, just in a different regard this session.

710.text: >> So a little into the next question, so life support, I mean those two ironically enough at this point

717.text: shouldn't be on life support, they should be in finalization phase if you compare it to past years.

723.text: What else is on life support that may have died off, might be coming back, what do you see in that?

730.text: >> One of the things that I find interesting, the Governor came out this week and asked for

736.text: $100 million for Visit Florida, which is $24 million more than they currently have.

740.text: And what I thought was interesting is the Governor has been the biggest advocate for

743.text: Enterprise Florida, those two kind of lumped together. Towards the end of session,

746.text: he seems to kind of be focusing more on Visit Florida and focusing requests there.

751.text: I wonder if that's bad news for Mike Grissom at Enterprise Florida,

754.text: in the sense that the Governor has changed his focus a little bit

758.text: and from a life support perspective there is the idea the House is trying to

762.text: kill Enterprise Florida, abolish it. The Governor is trying to get incentive money for it

766.text: and I wonder to what degree some legislation of the House dealing with Enterprise Florida

770.text: and the entity in general is gonna be part of this horse trade and could be on life support

775.text: if the Governor says, well, give me more money for my tourism marketing and

778.text: we can talk about this other thing that I've been a huge advocate for.

781.text: So I'm interested to see how that economic development thing plays out now that the Governor

785.text: has focused, it seems, more on Visit Florida than Enterprise Florida.

788.text: >> Well, he keeps saying Governor Scott, I think it's U.S. Senator Scott.

793.text: I mean he's been in D.C. more this week than anywhere else, and to our credit, I mean he's been...

798.text: he brought back the biggest win of the session is the $1.5 billion for the low income pool money.

803.text: I mean, that kind of changed the dynamic of session because it took off some of the pressure.

807.text: And then he brings home, I think yesterday, a commitment for federal funding for fixing the

812.text: dike down in South Florida, so I think Senator Scott is doing a great job.

816.text: If I were Senator Nelson, I would be very worried right now.

819.text: >> I think breaking news here is Peter just buried Bill Nelson here, the only statewide Democrat,

824.text: >> I think Bill Nelson buried Bill Nelson a long time ago. No, but you're right with the Visit Florida,

830.text: I've never seen those negotiations by the Governor where it's like, hey I want $74 million,

834.text: they come back with $25, it's like now I want a $100.

837.text: He's like wait we need to meet in the middle not...you just keep increasing.

841.text: >> But he has always generally tethered the two issues. It's always been Visit Florida/Enterprise Florida.

845.text: >> And you think he's given up. >> I don't think he's given up.

847.text: Giving up is too strong, but he called an impromptu press conference, which first off,

850.text: that's not like this Governor, he doesn't generally do it, and he didn't once mention Enterprise Florida.

854.text: He had Visit Florida. He had Ken Lawson there. He had the Chair of the Visit Florida Board

858.text: and there wasn't a sniff of Enterprise Florida, so I think giving up is

861.text: way too strong of a term at this point, but I thought it was definitely an interesting switch that was noticeable.

865.text: >> Brian? >> Look, Enterprise Florida is on life support, and it's gonna stay on life support through the

870.text: time Corcoran is Speaker of the House, there is no question about it.

874.text: It's not gonna go away though. I'm confident that they may strip funding from it,

878.text: but it's not gonna be eradicated or abolished, it's going to exist. I don't know how much money

884.text: they're gonna get, if any - probably zero it out this year - and that's why it's on life support.

888.text: It's gonna be on life support this year, next year and then it'll come back.

891.text: It's a popular program amongst business communities, amongst some of these folks from various districts,

896.text: and it is popular with the Governor. Whether it's popular with the next Governor, that's a different story.

902.text: So that's why it'll be on life support for the next two years.

905.text: >> So where does that leave our good friend Mike Grissom who's been the subject of many an article.

911.text: >> He's gonna be the next deputy editor at The Capitolist.

915.text: >> I think he'll remain as interim CEO. He knows how to navigate this environment.

920.text: I think he'll remain there, and there is no reason to install someone new when there is

922.text: no money to spend right now. Grissom will take care of the

926.text: >> But there're two different questions. We always talk about the economic incentives

929.text: which is above what their operational, what their base funding is.

931.text: If the House leadership and Speaker Corcoran won't even sign off on the $23 million in

936.text: operational funding that they have, what does that look like when they don't just have

940.text: no incentives, but don't have a budget.

942.text: >> I think they survive with just enough to operate. I think they'll stay alive.

948.text: They'll find a way to be as relevant as possible with a very thin budget.

954.text: >> You're asking questions about Mike Grissom, I think one of the questions you really have to

957.text: wonder about is what state agency will he land at next, because undoubtedly they'll be

963.text: zeroed out not soon thereafter, and so I'd keep an eye out for... >> Why are you picking on Mike Grissom?

969.text: >> I love Mike Grissom, and I see him every night at the Governor's Club.

972.text: >> Give him the Grim Reaper costume and send him off to DBPR or something?

975.text: >> I love Leslie Dougher's campaigng for a state party chair.  >> Trimmel?

978.text: >> It's a good strategy by the Governor to what Matt was talking about, that pivot.

984.text: It's not completely dead to not focus on Enterprise Florida but to just switch and

990.text: put all the attention over to Visit Florida. It's something that he has a lot of support coming out of,

995.text: he has...Florida is a tourism state, so there's a lot of people who are coming in.

1000.text: >> It was definitely the first component in the economic development world where you saw

1006.text: multiple sides kind of soften and come together on a conversation.

1009.text: It was the package that was there, but as you see it, that could be considered a winner

1016.text: currently in the process, but let's talk about other winners and losers that y'all see right now

1021.text: in session or who do you think ends up a winner and loser in the next few weeks?

1025.text: >> I am curious to see what will happen with Senator Scott, Governor Scott bringing that

1032.text: win from Washington to help with the Herbert Hoover Dike.

1037.text: How will that impact President Negron's plan for his push to fix Lake Okeechobee. >> Peter?

1045.text: >> I think a loser is Tom Lee. I think that he made a maneuver to be the House's guy in the Senate

1054.text: as Matt has written about in a great article behind the paywall this week,

1059.text: but he has alienated many of his colleagues. I thought it was atrocious that he was the

1066.text: first person to go over and shake Frank Artiles hand after that terrible apology,

1072.text: but he's also lost a lot of bills. I mean the scene this week where Jack Latvala and Dana Young

1078.text: are fighting with him over an investigation into the airport and yada yada,

1083.text: but that seems to be happening to a lot of Tom Lee bills right now. They keep losing.

1087.text: The only person that's losing more bills right now is Frank Artiles.

1092.text: >> Thanks for bringing up Frank Artiles. I think one of the biggest losers right now are

1095.text: Florida Democrats and that is because they have made more noise about this issue than anything else

1101.text: in the Florida session this entire session. They are wrapped up in it, it's pure identity politics

1107.text: and if they can all ban together on a couple of other issues they could actually be effective

1113.text: in a lot of different ways, but right now they have made this their main thing.

1118.text: Absolutely Artiles is probably doomed and possibly should be doomed.  We'll know more next week.

1124.text: He certainly shouldn't have said what he said, but I'm hearing rumors now that

1129.text: Al Sharpton and Jessie Jackson are coming down. Identity politics is not...oh you started the rumor,

1135.text: okay fair enough. >> I did start that rumor last night. >> Well it got to me very quickly.

1141.text: >> I think by design you started that rumor to get to Burgess, for today.

1144.text: >> Sabotage, at any rate, regardless whether they show up or whether they don't,

1148.text: whether that continues to be a focus through next week, we're talking about an

1153.text: $80 billion budget right now and the Artiles issue is what everybody is talking about.

1158.text: >> I also think they can see that, and maybe rightly so, as leverage for $82 or $83 billion budget

1163.text: you're talking about. The idea they stick together as a block and as a caucus and keep that

1166.text: drumbeat going and going and going. I'm not convinced that they can't translate that into

1171.text: real policy or funding wins. So I don't know that it's necessarily a bad idea.

1175.text: I think they have to, but I think where Peter is gonna go is in the past when someone tried to

1180.text: do this they screwed it up, but I think it's an okay strategy. It could work.

1185.text: >> Making fun of the Florida Democrats for being losers is like

1188.text: criticizing the Washington Generals for poor free throw shooting.

1194.text: I'm gonna pop you now, and I'm gonna get on my blog five minutes later.

1198.text: I mean to dismiss the Artiles situation as just identity politics, I think there are sometimes

1203.text: sins so egregious that even an $82 billion budget can be put on hold for a day or two

1210.text: to address a serious topic. >> $30 billion in state money.

1215.text: >> I think that we need to deal with the Artiles issue. I think the problem with the Artiles issue,

1220.text: if you want to go to your part of it is, it has thrown everything for delay of

1224.text: three or four days right now, but now this is serious enough where the Democrats,

1229.text: I think if Perry Thurston and Oscar do nothing else but get rid of a horrible person from the

1236.text: Florida Senate they would have accomplished something.

1239.text: >> He's not a popular figure at all. He's viewed as sort of a bit of a bully,

1243.text: and I don't know that he's gonna survive this thing. There's the hearing next week,

1247.text: the report coming out next week and that will largely sort of control his fate in my view.

1253.text: >> This is beyond politics, the incident with Artiles and it's not the first time we've had...

1261.text: every time I've covered Artiles, it has been more about a controversial issue from the bar fights

1267.text: to everything else in between, and his reputation is just known for just being this type of

1273.text: character that we heard about reported on in the Miami Herald.

1278.text: So it's outside of just identity politics, like you know you shouldn't be calling anyone these names,

1285.text: these words, these are the leaders of our state, so it's beyond that and listening to

1292.text: leader Braynon, he would say and he said that how this, they didn't design this,

1298.text: they didn't put words in his mouth to take this on as their cause, he did this to himself.

1303.text: So it's just common decency and decorum. It's a great argument.

1308.text: >> So that issue will continue to play out as we'll see between now and end of session and probably beyond.

1314.text: So let's move back to a discussion on issues and leadership.

1318.text: If you were Speaker Corcoran and you have now until the end of session,

1323.text: what do you care most about, about getting done between now and then?

1326.text: >> Making sure there is not one penny of economic incentives in the final budget.

1331.text: He sort of painted himself into a corner politically, the AFPs and some of the conservative

1337.text: outside groups of the world are largely expected to support him politically moving forward

1341.text: and to this point he's painted himself in a corner by saying, digging his heels and no incentives,

1346.text: we want to abolish Enterprise Florida. So if he keeps all of those out,

1350.text: if he follows through with that, I think that would be a big win for him and that would be my focus.

1355.text: I mean, if there's $10,000 from some random film incentive in the final budget,

1359.text: it's a rounding error as far as the total budget, but it's going to become an issue for him.

1363.text: >> It's philosophical, at that point.  >> I think you have got to not snatch defeat from the

1367.text: jaws of victory. This has been the Richard Corcoran session.

1370.text: It has been the Richard Corcoran show. He is the big winner. He has set the table.

1375.text: I said this to him the other day. I've written it, get out of here, get out on time, get a budget.

1380.text: You've won, you have changed the game, but I see all these things like he launches an

1384.text: investigation into this, he wants an audit of that, and that's the criticism of the Speaker is

1389.text: that he loves the game so much that he doesn't know how to win it.

1392.text: Get out of here. Get out on Cinco de Mayo. Have a margarita and be done.

1398.text: If you gotta come back and do the budget, that's fine but take a break.

1402.text: >> But we're calling him the winner, but there's a chance that the Senate President gets his

1406.text: number one priority, the reservoir bill. It's been rewritten, and we keep focusing on Corcoran and

1410.text: Speaker Corcoran as the big winner, but if that bill passes, I think

1413.text: President Negron quietly did the only thing he wanted to do here.

1418.text: >> Held the line on a lot of conservative issues and then pass this thing which is

1421.text: very important to his constituents where he lives.  >> Right.

1425.text: So he could be winning on his number one bill while Speaker Corcoran has all bills that

1432.text: he has to stop or maintain. >> He has to hold the line.

1435.text: Corcoran has to hold the line, and I think by contrast, I agree with what you said, Peter,

1438.text: and if you look back to like the 2011 Session, Mike Haridopolos was running for Senate

1444.text: at the same time that he was >> Who? >> Exactly...at the same time he was running his first term as

1450.text: the Senate President and having that knowledge, the other members knowing that he's got a

1456.text: political agenda beyond session can be used as leverage, so Richard Corcoran is in a dangerous spot,

1461.text: but he's also is in the driver's seat, and as long as he can hold the line,

1464.text: I think he'll emerge as a big winner, but he's gonna have to do that.

1468.text: >> Alright, so let's look at the last days of session. What should we brace for, what's unexpected?

1473.text: What do you guys see that could just absolutely change both our world and perhaps Florida's

1480.text: between now and the end of session?

1482.text: >> Regardless, for Corcoran, I think the plume that he has left with all the changes that he's done,

1488.text: it would be seen as a win for him if he does not get everything he wants,

1493.text: because he has just torn everything up.

1495.text: We're all focused on him, his impressions have changed like people who are not,

1500.text: typically would not be supportive of him are saying, like look at Corcoran, look at this guy.

1505.text: He's on their radar so this is boding well for him and whatever else he does.

1511.text: >> I think the gambling bill will be interesting, at least for another week.

1516.text: I think they will conference, and they'll either make progress and then be able to get something done

1521.text: or we'll blow up again like the Peanuts character, but I would be remiss if we didn't mention it.

1527.text: Latvala magic. I mean, it's gotta come. I mean Jack has been growling but he has not,

1533.text: we have not seen Latvala magic yet. It is coming into his end of the pool right now, the budget,

1539.text: the parliamentary procedures, etc. I think he's gonna say, I think he's gonna look at Joe Negron

1546.text: and, "hold my beer," and come out there and make his presence felt in the last two weeks.

1552.text: >> He hasn't won a race in a very long time, but this is his time. He's magic in the building.

1556.text: >> Alright, well, special session, do we go or don't we?

1560.text: >> I don't think so. I've been saying it, people were predicting special session before

1564.text: regular session started. I've always said that was premature. I said it in public settings before.

1568.text: Wouldn't shock me, I guess, but if you ask me with a gun to my head, I'm gonna say we get out on time.

1574.text: >> There are Senate staffers who are floating rumors, but I do believe

1579.text: - about forcing a special session - but I do believe that is more of a Jack Latvala sort of

1584.text: trying to create a little extra pressure.

1587.text: >> I did not think, I thought we were not going to, now I do.

1592.text: The Artiles thing throws off the timing for the next two or three days.

1596.text: You know they need seven days to conference from community chairs, appropriation chairs, leaders.

1601.text: That puts you to Monday or Tuesday, I don't know, maybe they get out at Saturday at

1605.text: four in the morning, but I think there will be a cooling off period and bills are dying and

1610.text: all that stuff, and they come back a couple weeks later and do the budget.

1613.text: >> Trimmel, last word. >> I think, I'll leave it open, we don't know

1618.text: and that's what's happening around the Capitol. People are wondering, well, what's next

1621.text: and to my earlier point, people want to be in the head of Richard Corcoran to see

1625.text: what's really gonna happen and who's gonna kick things up.

1627.text: >> Alright, the Corcoran cabeza, that is the topic of the day.

1632.text: Well, gentlemen, thank you very much for joining us on Capital Dateline,

1634.text: and we look forward to seeing y'all again soon.
